column8: Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg plans to spend at least $100 million to help Democratic nominee Joe Biden win the crucial battleground state of Florida. Bloomberg's late-stage infusion of cash reflects Democrats' concerns about the tight race in Florida, where polls show a close race and no financial advantage for President Donald Trump. Bloomberg's spending will allow the Biden campaign to invest more heavily in other key states like Pennsylvania. Even before Bloomberg's spending, both campaigns were expecting Florida to be the most expensive state in which to campaign. Trump won the state by a narrow margin in 2016, and recent polls show Biden with a slim lead. Bloomberg's money will be used for television and digital advertising, with a focus on reaching Latino voters. The move may put pressure on Republicans and the Trump campaign to spend more in Florida, leaving less money to spend elsewhere. Bloomberg, who spent $1 billion on his own failed presidential bid, has pledged to help Democrats defeat Trump regardless of his own campaign's outcome.

column3: It protects social media companies from liability for what their users post—positioning them as platforms instead of publishers.
column4: President Donald Trump has threatened to veto the $740 billion National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) unless it includes a measure eliminating Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which protects tech companies from liability over user-generated content. Trump and Republican lawmakers have criticized internet platforms for their content moderation decisions, accusing them of stifling conservative voices. The Internet Association, which includes Facebook, Amazon, Google, and Twitter, has criticized Trump's move, stating that repealing Section 230 is a threat to national security as it empowers online platforms to remove harmful and dangerous content. The NDAA sets policy for the Department of Defense and has been passed annually for six decades. Congressional aides expressed skepticism that Trump would actually veto the legislation, suggesting that his threat was part of an effort to force revisions to Section 230 and include them in the defense bill. Trump has previously pulled back from threats to derail legislation.

column3: The beneficiaries included three GOP congressmen who separately were convicted of or pleaded guilty to various corruption charges, two individuals caught up in the Mueller investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election investigation, and four ex-security contractors who were convicted for their involvement in the 2007 killings of 17 unarmed Iraqi civilians in Baghdad.
column4: President Donald Trump has pardoned his former campaign chairman Paul Manafort, his longtime adviser Roger Stone, and Charles Kushner, the father of his son-in-law and adviser Jared Kushner. The move sparked blowback, mostly from Democrats, who accused him of wielding his executive authority to shield himself from possible criminal investigation. Trump had previously resisted offering Manafort a pardon, likely in part because doing so posed a political risk. His decision to move forward now appeared at least a tacit acknowledgment that his presidency is nearing an end, despite asserting without evidence that he was robbed of a victory by widespread election fraud.

column3: Trump has granted 29 pardons and commuted 16 prison sentences during his presidency.
column4: The U.S. Justice Department is investigating a potential bribery scheme involving the White House and presidential pardons, according to court documents unsealed on Tuesday. The documents, which were heavily redacted, revealed that prosecutors were investigating a “bribery-for-pardon“ scheme in which someone would offer a substantial political contribution in exchange for a presidential pardon or reprieve of sentence. The investigation also involves a “secret lobbying scheme“ in which two unidentified individuals acted as lobbyists to senior White House officials without complying with the registration requirement of the Lobbying Disclosure Act. The court documents did not name any individuals involved in the alleged schemes, and it is unclear whether President Trump is connected to the investigation. The Justice Department has said that no government official is or was a target of the investigation. The release of the court documents comes as Trump is reportedly considering a series of pardons in his final weeks in office. Last week, he pardoned his former national security adviser Michael Flynn, who had pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI during the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

The documents, which were heavily redacted, revealed that prosecutors were investigating a “bribery-for-pardon“ scheme in which someone would offer a substantial political contribution in exchange for a presidential pardon or reprieve of sentence. The investigation also involves a “secret lobbying scheme“ in which two unidentified individuals acted as lobbyists to senior White House officials without complying with the registration requirement of the Lobbying Disclosure Act. The court documents did not name any individuals involved in the alleged schemes, and it is unclear whether President Trump is connected to the investigation. The Justice Department has said that no government official is or was a target of the investigation. The release of the court documents comes as Trump is reportedly considering a series of pardons in his final weeks in office. Last week, he pardoned his former national security adviser Michael Flynn, who had pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI during the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

McConnell's decision to move forward with a nomination has led to calls from Democrats to eliminate the filibuster and possibly expand the Supreme Court if they gain control of the White House and Senate. McConnell's move also puts vulnerable Republican senators in a difficult position, as they face tough reelection battles and must decide whether to support a nomination before the election. The battle over Ginsburg's seat is expected to be a major campaign issue and could have significant consequences for the court and its decisions on issues such as abortion rights and healthcare.

column3: A federal judge ruled Tuesday morning that the Justice Department is not allowed to replace President Trump’s personal lawyers and defend him in a defamation lawsuit filed by E. Jean Carroll, an author who accused him of rape, which he has vehemently denied.
column4: A federal judge has rejected a request by the US Department of Justice (DOJ) to represent President Donald Trump in a defamation lawsuit brought by writer E. Jean Carroll. Carroll has accused Trump of raping her in a Manhattan department store in the 1990s. The DOJ had argued that the US should replace Trump as the defendant in the case, as he was acting in his official capacity when he denied the allegations. However, Judge Lewis Kaplan ruled that Trump was not an employee of the government and that his comments about Carroll were unrelated to his official duties. Carroll’s lawyer, Roberta Kaplan, said the ruling was a “clear victory” for her client. Carroll is seeking unspecified damages and a retraction of Trump’s statements. She also wants a DNA sample from Trump to compare with genetic material found on a dress she says she was wearing during the alleged assault.

Carroll has accused Trump of raping her in a Manhattan department store in the 1990s. The DOJ had argued that the US should replace Trump as the defendant in the case, as he was acting in his official capacity when he denied the allegations. However, Judge Lewis Kaplan ruled that Trump was not an employee of the government and that his comments about Carroll were unrelated to his official duties. Carroll’s lawyer, Roberta Kaplan, said the ruling was a “clear victory” for her client. Carroll is seeking unspecified damages and a retraction of Trump’s statements. She also wants a DNA sample from Trump to compare with genetic material found on a dress she says she was wearing during the alleged assault.

column3: The Department of Justice on Tuesday filed a lawsuit against Stephanie Winston Wolkoff over her recently published tell-all book discussing First Lady Melania Trump, to whom she previously served as an assistant.
column4: The U.S. Justice Department has filed a lawsuit against Stephanie Winston Wolkoff, author of a tell-all book about First Lady Melania Trump, accusing her of breaking their nondisclosure agreement. The lawsuit claims that Winston Wolkoff, a former aide to the first lady, failed to submit a draft of her book for government review, as required by her agreement. The book, titled “Melania and Me: The Rise and Fall of My Friendship with the First Lady,“ offers an unflattering portrayal of Melania Trump. The government is seeking to set aside profits from the book and any subsequent movie deals or documentaries in a government trust. Winston Wolkoff has responded to the lawsuit, stating that she fulfilled all the terms of her agreement and that the confidentiality provisions ended when the White House terminated the agreement. She argues that the government's use of the Justice Department to silence her is a violation of her First Amendment rights. The book, which was published six weeks ago, was a New York Times bestseller and sells for $16.80 on Amazon. The lawsuit against Winston Wolkoff is similar to the Justice Department's attempts to stop the publication of a book by former Trump national security adviser John Bolton.

column3: WATCH:
column4: The Republican-led U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee has scheduled an Oct. 22 vote on the confirmation of Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court, despite objections from Democrats. The committee's decision came after four days of confirmation hearings, during which Democrats criticized the rushed nature of the proceedings and Barrett's refusal to answer questions on key issues. Republicans are aiming for a final confirmation vote on the Senate floor by the end of October. With Republicans holding a majority in the Senate, Barrett's confirmation seems assured, which would give the Supreme Court a 6-3 conservative majority. Democrats have expressed concerns that Barrett's confirmation could threaten abortion rights and the Affordable Care Act. Barrett has promised to keep an open mind on major issues that may come before the court, including abortion and healthcare. The committee's decision to move forward with the confirmation process has been met with criticism from Democrats, who argue that the nomination should wait until after the election. However, Republicans argue that they are well within their rights to confirm a nominee before the election.

column3: By MARK SHERMAN, LISA MASCARO and MARY CLARE JALONICK, Associated Press
column4: The Republican-led U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee has scheduled an Oct. 22 vote on the confirmation of Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court, despite objections from Democrats. The committee's decision came after four days of confirmation hearings, during which Democrats criticized the rushed nature of the proceedings and Barrett's refusal to answer questions on key issues. Republicans are aiming for a final confirmation vote on the Senate floor by the end of October. With Republicans holding a majority in the Senate, Barrett's confirmation seems assured, which would give the Supreme Court a 6-3 conservative majority. Democrats have expressed concerns that Barrett's confirmation could threaten abortion rights and the Affordable Care Act. Barrett has promised to keep an open mind on major issues that may come before the court, including abortion and healthcare. The committee's decision to move forward with the confirmation process has been met with criticism from Democrats, who argue that the nomination should wait until after the election. However, Republicans argue that they are well within their rights to confirm a nominee before the election.

column3: 5 days ago By MARK SHERMAN, LISA MASCARO and MARY CLARE JALONICK, Associated Press

column3: But several top GOP senators are warning that the defense bill isn’t the right arena for Trump to dig in on the tech battle, which has emerged as a top target for the president and conservative allies.
column4: Congress is moving forward on a must-pass defense policy bill without repealing a legal shield for social media companies, rejecting a last-minute veto threat from President Donald Trump. The final version of the National Defense Authorization Act that will soon be considered by the House and Senate won’t include Trump’s long-sought repeal of the legal immunity for online companies, known as Section 230, according to lawmakers and aides. Republicans also made clear they weren’t going to bend to Trump. Senate Armed Services Chair Jim Inhofe (R-Okla.) said that while he agrees with Trump on Section 230, the provision “has nothing to do with the military.” “You can’t do it in this bill. That’s not a part of the bill,” Inhofe said, adding that he has conveyed that belief to Trump. In a pair of tweets Tuesday evening, Trump threatened to veto the bill if it does not include a full repeal of Section 230, which he has criticized as an unfair protection for social media companies whom the president believes are biased against him.

Senate Armed Services Chair Jim Inhofe (R-Okla.) said that while he agrees with Trump on Section 230, the provision “has nothing to do with the military.” “You can’t do it in this bill. That’s not a part of the bill,” Inhofe said, adding that he has conveyed that belief to Trump. In a pair of tweets Tuesday evening, Trump threatened to veto the bill if it does not include a full repeal of Section 230, which he has criticized as an unfair protection for social media companies whom the president believes are biased against him.

Trump’s pardon, which could be the first of several after he lost the 2020 presidential election to Democrat Joe Biden, drew condemnation from Democrats and other critics. A retired Army general, Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about interactions he had with Russia’s ambassador to the United States in the weeks leading up to Trump’s inauguration in January 2017. He has since sought to withdraw the plea, arguing that prosecutors violated his rights and duped him into a plea agreement. His sentencing has been deferred several times.

column4: Democratic Representative Jeff Van Drew, who has been strongly opposed to impeaching President Donald Trump, is reportedly planning to switch parties and become a Republican. Van Drew is one of two Democrats who voted against opening the impeachment inquiry into Trump and has remained against the effort. His decision comes after a meeting with Trump on Friday. Van Drew's staff and other members of the New Jersey delegation were informed of his plans to switch parties on Saturday. It is still unclear if Van Drew will make the announcement before the House votes on impeachment, which is expected next week. Republicans are excited about the news, seeing it as a blow to Democrats' impeachment efforts. However, Democrats are brushing off the party switch, saying it is purely based on politics and voters will see through his motivations. Van Drew's departure is unlikely to impact the impeachment vote tally, as Democratic leadership had already expected a handful of members to vote against impeachment. Van Drew's approval ratings are under water with Democratic voters in his district, and a recent poll showed that only 24% of Democratic primary voters believe he deserves to be reelected.

column4: Democratic Representative Jeff Van Drew, who has been strongly opposed to impeaching President Donald Trump, is reportedly planning to switch parties and become a Republican. Van Drew is one of two Democrats who voted against opening the impeachment inquiry into Trump and has remained against the effort. His decision comes after a meeting with Trump on Friday. Van Drew's staff and other members of the New Jersey delegation were informed of his plans to switch parties on Saturday. It is still unclear if Van Drew will make the announcement before the House votes on impeachment, which is expected next week. Republicans are excited about the news, seeing it as a blow to Democrats' impeachment efforts. However, Democrats are brushing off the party switch, saying it is purely based on politics and voters will see through his motivations. column3: Stephen Biegun, the U.S. special envoy for North Korea, arrived in South Korea on Sunday as Pyongyang stepped up pressure on Washington to make concessions to revive stalled denuclearisation talks ahead of a year-end deadline.
column4: Stephen Biegun, the U.S. special envoy for North Korea, arrived in South Korea on Sunday as North Korea increased pressure on the United States to make concessions in order to revive stalled denuclearization talks before the year-end deadline. Biegun's arrival followed North Korea's announcement that it had conducted another “crucial test“ at a rocket launch site to develop a strategic weapon to deter U.S. nuclear threats. Analysts believe that these tests could help North Korea build more reliable intercontinental ballistic missiles capable of reaching the United States. Biegun did not make any comments upon his arrival. During his three-day stay in South Korea, he plans to meet with South Korean President Moon Jae-in before heading to Tokyo to consult with his Japanese counterpart. It is unclear whether he will meet with North Korean officials at the inter-Korean border. Biegun's trip has led to speculation that he may try to salvage negotiations by reaching out to North Korea or by publicly sending a message. Despite three meetings between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and U.S. President Donald Trump, there has been little progress in negotiating an end to North Korea's nuclear and missile programs.
